104th Division (Institutional Training)
Timberwolf Division
https://www.globalsecurity.org/military/agency/army/images/104d.gif

The 104th Division was located at Vancouver Barracks in Vancouver, but recommended in the 2005 BRAC Recommendations to relocate to Fort Lewis, WA. Washington with subordinate units throughout the twelve Western States. The Division is Commanded by a Major General.

In September 1996 the 104th Division welcomed 15 United States Army Reserve Schools to the Division. The Division undergoes a transition from an OSUT Division to a Division (Institutional Training) unit. During Annual Training, units of the First Brigade supplement an Active Army Training Battalion at Fort Sill, Oklahoma and assume the full time training of 800 new soldiers per year. The 7th Brigade (Training Support) has responsibility for training Reserve Officet Training Corps (ROTC) Cadets at Fort Lewis, Washington. In addition, they train new drill sergeants and in-process new soldiers. TASS or the School Brigade units instruct officer and NCO professional development courses. They also provide Military Occupational Skill (MOS) instruction for over 80,000 Army Reserve and National Guard soldiers from throughout the twelve Western States.
https://www.globalsecurity.org/military/agency/army/images/104d-2.gif

Constituted 24 June 1921 in the Organized Reserves as Headquarters, 104th Division. Organized 7 October 1921 at Salt Lake City, Utah. Redesignated 6 April 1942 as Division Headquarters, 104th Division. Ordered into active military service 15 September 1942 and reorganized at Camp Adair, Oregon, as Headquarters, 104th Infantry Division.

Members of the 104th Infantry Division, known as "Timberwolves," still get inspiration from the slogan of a former commanding general, Terry Allen: "Nothing in hell can stop the Timberwolves." Allen commanded the 104th during its most trying months of World War II, when it battled Adolf Hitler's Wehrmacht troops in Western Europe.

The 104th Infantry Division landed in France on 7 September 1944. It moved into defensive positions in the vicinity of Wuestwezel, Belgium, 23 October 1944, and went over to the, offensive on the 26th, taking Zundert, gaining control of the Breda-Roosendaal Road and overrunning Vaart Canal defenses. Leur and Etten fell as the Division advanced to the Mark River, 31 October. A coordinated attack over the Mark River at Standaarduiten, 2 November 1944, established a bridgehead. Zevenbergen was captured and the Maas River reached on 5 November. While the bulk of the Division moved near Aachen, Germany, elements remained to secure Moerdijk before being relieved on 7 November.

The 104th attacked, 16 November, taking Stolberg and pushing on against heavy resistance. Eschweiler fell on the 21st and the enemy was cleared from the area west of the Inde River including Inden by 2 December. Lucherberg was held against enemy counterattacks on 3 December, and all strongholds west of the Roer River were captured by the 23d. The 104th actively defended its sector near Duren and Merken from 15 December 1944 to 22 February 1945. Then it moved across the Roer taking Huchem-Stammeln, Birkesdorf, and North Duren. On 5 March, after heavy fighting, it entered Koln. After defending the west bank of the Rhine, the Division crossed the river at Honnef, 22 March 1945, and attacked to the east of the Remagen bridgehead. After a period of mopping up and consolidation, it participated in the trap of enemy troops in the Ruhr pocket. The 104th repulsed heavy attacks near Medebach and captured Paderborn, 1 April 1945. After regrouping, it advanced to the east and crossed the Weser River on the 8th, blocking enemy exits from the Harz Mountains. The Division then crossed the Saale River and took Halle in a bitter 5-day struggle, 15 to 19 April. The sector to the Mulde River was cleared by the 21st, and after vigorous patrolling, the Division contacted the Red Army at Pretzsch, 26 April. The 104th left for home and inactivation 27 June.

The 104th Infantry Division was inactivated 20 December 1945 at Camp San Luis Obispo, California. Activated 1 December 1946 at Portland, Oregon. (Organized Reserves redesignated 25 March 1948 as the Organized Reserve Corps; redesignated 9 July 1952 as the Army Reserve.) The 104th Division turned out 300 reservists for its first summer training camp in July 1948. By 1952, the number had grown to 1,500, and in later years even more were involved in training. Reorganized and redesignated 10 June 1959 as Headquarters and Headquarters Company, 104th Division (Training). Location changed 1 November 1961 to Vancouver Barracks, Washington.

In October 1978 the Division implemented the new mission of an Infantry One Station Unit Training (OSUT) program which combined Basic Combat Training (BCT) , Advanced Individual Training (AIT) and Combat Support Training (CST). The Division consisted of Headquarters and Headquarters Company, Training Group, Leadership Academy, 1st, 2nd, 3rd, and 4th Brigades, and the 6218th Reception Battalion and was dispersed over the states of Washingtom, Oregon, and California.

In its 2005 BRAC Recommendations, DoD recommended to relocate the 104th Division (IT) to Fort Lewis; its former home, Vancouver Barracks, was recommended for closure. This recommendation associated with this move would transform Army Reserve command and control by consolidating two major headquarters onto Fort Lewis.
108th Division (Institutional Training)
https://www.globalsecurity.org/military/agency/army/images/108d.gif

The 108th Division (Institutional Training) is one of several Army Reserve training divisions in the Army's force structure. The 108th Division now has 3,300 soldiers assigned to units over 200,000 square miles in four states and Puerto Rico in 23 cities and towns.

The 108th Division was activated in 1946 following World War II. Then called the 108th Airborne Division, it was headquartered in Atlanta, Georgia. The division's nickname, the Golden Griffons, was born from its initial air-ground mission. Griffons are legendary animals from Greek mythology who are half-lion, half-eagle and eight times the size of a lion. Known for their courage and ferocity, griffons were so feared by ancient people that rulers of Asian provinces used them to guard their vast treasures.

Over its history, the 108th Division frequently has been called upon to pilot several new missions for the Army and Army Reserve. Over the years, the division has played an important role in pioneering and developing several training methods and policies still in use today.

In 1952, the division was reorganized into an infantry division and its headquarters was moved to its present location in Charlotte, North Carolina with all its subordinate units located in either North or South Carolina. In 1954, the division helped test a new method of rifle qualification known as "trainfire." In 1956, the division was selected to serve as a prototype for an Army Training Division. This meant reorganizing again to conduct basic and advanced individual training, should the division be called to active duty.

In the 1960's, the division established its own drill sergeant school patterned after the active component school. In 1968, the 108th Division was restructured under its current brigade concept. During the Vietnam era, 108th Division soldiers during annual training were used to conduct interim training for soldiers waiting to begin basic training. In the 1980's the division developed an updated and more practical mobilization plan. During those same years the division began conducting basic training at Fort Jackson under new Mobilization Army Training Center and Provisional Training concepts.

In January of 1991, more than 300 108th Division soldiers were called to active duty to support Operation Desert Storm, marking the first mobilization ever for members of the 108th Division. Division soldiers assisted in the retraining of individual soldiers at Fort Jackson who were called back to military duty.

In late 1993, the 108th Division accepted the mission to pilot a new concept in Army training called Future Army Schools Twenty-first Century. This not only expanded the geographic size of the 108th Division to add the states of Georgia and Florida, but added 10 new U.S Army Reserve Forces Schools to the division's force structure. Those schools were later reorganized into functionally-aligned school brigades. This gave the 108th Division a new mission. While keeping the mission of conducting initial entry training for new soldiers entering the Army, it now conducts specialized skill training for thousands of soldiers, both officers and enlisted, in the southeastern part of the United States. In 1993, the Division was reorganized into two IET training brigades, a training support brigade, and four school brigades responsible for training IET soldiers missions and providing enlisted and officer courses within Region "C". The school brigades teach enlisted MOS producing courses, BNCOC and ANCOC enlisted advanced training courses, and in the case of one brigade, professional development courses to officers. This training is provided in both IDT and AT formats to the U.S. Army Reserves and National Guard across the four states comprising Region "C"

In 1996 the 108th Division was assigned another completely new mission as part of a pilot project to conduct Reserve Officer Training Corps training at three colleges and universities in Florida, Georgia and South Carolina. That pilot now has been expanded nationally and the 108th Division formally added a ROTC group to its organizational structure. In October of 1998, the 108th Division assumed command and control of the former 265th US Army Forces School in Puerto Rico, which added an 8th Brigade.
1st Brigade, 108th Division

During peacetime, 1st Brigade Drill Sergeants, supported by Company and Battalion training, administrative and logistical personnel, provide year round training in support of active Army BCT units, Army Reserve, National Guard, ROTC and JROTC units throughout Region C (North Carolina, South Carolina, Georgia, Flrida, and Puerto Rico).

During summer and fall months, 1st Brigade training companies expand the Army's training base in order to train the increased number of soldiers entering Basic Combat Training (BCT). Each training company performs a two week portion of the 9 week BCT POI.

The Headquarters Headquarters Detachment for the 1st Brigade (BCT) is centrally located within the brigade amongst subordinate battalions in Spartanburg, South Carolina. The detachment is commanded by a company grade officer to support the brigade commander, brigade command sergeant major, and primary brigade staff functions throughout the year. While providing normal detachment support in both administrative and training tasks, the unit normally deploys to Fort Jackson, South Carolina for annual training.
1-321st Regiment
images/321rgt.gif
1-518th Regiment
https://www.globalsecurity.org/military/agency/army/images/518rgt.gif

During pre mobilization, the 1st Battalion, 518h Regiment, augments Ft Jackson Basic Combat Training (BCT) capabilities through Drill Sergeant Partnership Programs and Annual Training in Echo Company configuration while preparing for post mobilization missions. On order, under post mobilization conditions, this unit will conduct Individual Ready Reserve Refresher Training under the command and control of the 1st Brigade (BCT), our regular peacetime trace with a secondary mission of Basic Combat Training when required.

The unit was constituted 15 July 1946 in the Organized Reserves as the 518th Parachuted Infantry and assigned to the 108th Airborne Division. It was activated 6 August 1946 with Headquarters at Charlotte, North Carolina. (Organized Reserves redesignated Organized Reserve Corps 25 March 1948.)

The unit was redesignated 28 February 1951 as the 518th Airborne Infantry. It was reorganized and redesignated as the 518th Infantry and assigned to the 108th Infantry Division 1 March 1952. (Organized Reserve Corps redesignated Army Reserve 9 July 1952.) It was relieved from the 108th Infantry Division 30 April 1959 and redesignated as the 518th Regiment (Basic Combat Training).
2-485th Regiment
https://www.globalsecurity.org/military/agency/army/images/485rgt.gif

The unit mission is to conduct Basic Combat Training for volunteers entering the U.S. Army. It develops soldiers who understand and are guided by the Army core values, train on basic soldier skills, and display appropriate discipline and motivation.
3-323rd Regiment

During pre mobilization, the 3d Battalion, 323d Regiment, augments Ft Jackson Basic Combat Training (BCT) capabilities through Drill Sergeant Partnership Programs and Annual Training in Echo Company configuration while preparing for post mobilization missions. On order, under post mobilization conditions, and in the event that the 1st Brigade (BCT) is mobilized, the 3rd Battalion (BCT) 323d Regiment will come under the command of the 2d Brigade (BCT), and will prepare to conduct basic combat training as directed by HQs 2d Brigade (BCT).

The unit was constituted 5 August 1917 in the National Army as 323d Infantry, an element of the 81st Division. It was organized 29 August 1917, at Camp Jackson, SC. Demobilized 17 - 30 June 1919, at Camp Lee, VA; Camp Jackson, SC; Camp Gordon, GA, Camp Upton, NY; and Camp Dix, NJ. The unit was reconstituted 24 June 1921, allotted to the Organized Reserves, and organized December 1921 at Knoxville, Tn, as an element of the 81st Division.

The unit was ordered into active military service at Camp Rucker, AL, 15 June 1942. It was later inactivated 20 January 1946, at Hirosaki, Japan. It was activated 6 November - 19 December 1946, with Headquarters at Clemson, SC. The unit was relieved from assignment to 81st Infantry Division and assigned to the 108th Infantry Division, 1 March 1952. The unit was resignated and reorganized 30 April 1959 as 323d Regiment (Basic Combat Training); an element of the 108th Division (Training).
3-518th Regiment
https://www.globalsecurity.org/military/agency/army/images/518rgt.gif

During pre mobilization, the 3rd Battalion, 518h Regiment, augments Ft Jackson Basic Combat Training (BCT) capabilities through Drill Sergeant Partnership Programs and Annual Training in Echo Company configuration while preparing for post mobilization missions. On order, under post mobilization conditions, this unit will conduct Individual Ready Reserve Refresher Training under the command and control of the 1st Brigade (BCT), our regular peacetime trace with a secondary mission of Basic Combat Training when required.

Annual Training involves training BCT soldiers at Fort Jackson, South Carolina. On weekend drills, the unit routinely provides BCT support to Reserve, National Guard, and ROTC units in areas of western North Carolina.

The unit was constituted 15 July 1946 in the Organized Reserves as the 518th Parachuted Infantry and assigned to the 108th Airborne Division. It was later activated 6 August 1946 with Headquarters at Charlotte, North Carolina. (Organized Reserves redesignated Organized Reserve Corps 25 March 1948.)

The unit was redesignated 28 February 1951 as the 518th Airborne Infantry. It was reorganized and redesignated as the 518th Infantry and assigned to the 108th Infantry Division 1 March 1952. (Organized Reserve Corps redesignated Army Reserve 9 July 1952.) It was relieved from the 108th Infantry Division 30 April 1959 and redesignated as the 518th Regiment (Basic Combat Training).
2nd Brigade, 108th Division
1-485th Regiment
https://www.globalsecurity.org/military/agency/army/images/485rgt.gif

The unit was constituted 15 July 1946 in the Organized Reserves as the 485th Glider Infantry and assigned to the 108th Airborne Division. It was activated 6 August 1946 with Headquarters at Jacksonville, FL. (Organized Reserves redesignated Organized Reserve Corps 25 March 1948.) Redesignated 28 February 1951 as the 485th Airborne Infantry.

The unit was relieved from the 108th Airborne Division, reorganized and redesignated as the 485th Infantry and assigned to the 87th Infantry Division 1 March 1952. (Organized Reserve Corps redesignated Army Reserve 9 July 1952.) Inactivated 31 March 1956 at Jacksonville, FL.
It was relieved from the 87th Infantry Division 1 April 1959 and redesignated as the 485th Regiment (Advanced Individual Training).
3rd Brigade, 108th Division
1-108th Regiment (Engineers)
2-108th Regiment (MP)

A part of The Army School System (TASS), 2-108 conducts military police MOS conversion training and NCOES training for U.S. Army Reserve and Army National Guard units in TASS Region C, which comprises North Carolina, South Carolina, Georgia, and Florida.
3-108th Regiment (Signal)
The war time mission of the 3rd Bn (SC), 108th Regt is to provide instructor personnel to an Army TRADOC installation as directed by our proponent, the US Army Signal School, Ft. Gordon, GA.

The peace time mission of the 3rd Bn (SC), 108th Regt conducts NCOES and Signal MOSQ Training to educate soldiers in signal career management fields CMF 31 and CMF 74, preparing them for the conduct of military operations during periods of peace, conflict and war.
4-108th Regiment (Chemical)
A part of The Army School System (TASS), 4-108 conducts chemical MOS training and NCOES training for U.S. Army Reserves and Army National Guard units in TASS Region C.
5-108th Regiment (Civil Affairs)
The 5-108th Regiment provides information to the US Army Reserves, National Guard and US Marine Corps Reserve units regarding Civil Affairs and Psychological Operations training in Region C.
6-108th Regiment (Military Intelligence)

The 6th Battalion (Military Intelligence), 108th Regiment, 3rd Brigade (Combat Support), 108th Division (Institutional Training) is a U.S. Army Reserve Intelligence School headquartered at Fort Bragg, NC. The 6th Battalion conducts specialized MI skill training (MOS reclassification and NCOES professional development courses) during Inactive Duty Training (IDT) and Annual Training (AT) for Reserve Component soldiers in the Southeastern U.S. (Region C and D). Upon mobilization, the battalion would support the U.S. Army Intelligence Center and School at Ft Huachuca, AZ as required to support the Army's buildup during war.
4th Brigade, 108th Division
7th Battalion (PSS)

The battalion is the personnel services training battalion of the 4th Brigade (CSS), 108th Division (IT) for Region C (NC, SC, GA, FL). The mission of the battalion is to provide instructors to provide training to enable Finance and Adjutant General Corps soldiers to attain needed military education and proficiency standards. 5th Brigade, 108th Division (Health Services)

The 5th Brigade's mission is to support IDT and AT phases for the medical density MOS and NCOES courses as accredited by TRADOC and aligned with the Academy of Health and Sciences. The headquarters of the 5th BDE (HS) is located in Jacksonville, Florida. Dispersed training cells throughout North Carolina, South Carolina, Georgia, and Florida allow the unit to effectively carry out its mission.
6th Brigade, 108th Division

Its mission is to provide subject matter to instruct Drill Sergeant candidates and NCOES/OES courses; to maintain the highest level of mobilization preparedness; and to be physically fit and professionally competent to conduct training to Army standards using Army Values.
11th Battalion (C&GS)
12th Battalion (CAS3)
To train Army Reserve, National Guard, and Active Component Officers to function as staff officers and members of a joint and or combined arms team in the United States Army.
On Feb 8th, 2001, the 12th Battalion, 6th Brigade was reaccredited.
7th Brigade, 108th Division (TS)
3-321st Regiment
https://www.globalsecurity.org/military/agency/army/images/321rgt.gif
2-518th Regiment (Rec / T&E)
https://www.globalsecurity.org/military/agency/army/images/518rgt.gif

During peacetime it conducts Reception Activity training at Home Station & Fort Jackson, Train to Standard on METL, Ensure soldiers qualify in APFT/AWQ/CTT, and support ROTC Advanced Camp Mission at Fort Lewis Washington.

Constituted 15 July 1946 in the Organized Reserves as the 518th Parachuted Infantry and assigned to the 108th Airborne Division. Activated 6 August 1946 with Headquarters at Charlotte, North Carolina. (Organized Reserves redesignated Organized Reserve Corps 25 March 1948.) Redesignated 28 February 1951 as the 518th Airborne Infantry. Reorganized and redesignated as the 518th Infantry and assigned to the 108th Infantry Division 1 March 1952. (Organized Reserve Corps redesignated Army Reserve 9 July 1952.) Relieved from the 108th Infantry Division 30 April 1959 and redesignated as the 518th Regiment.
8th Brigade, 108th Division (TS)

The mission of the Headquarters, Headquarters Detachment is to provide support to 8th Brigade Commander, Staff, and Battatalions in the conduct of the Total Army School System courses for the reserve Component, Active Component and National Guard Soldier.
1st Battalion

The Mission of the 1st Battalion (Combat Support) is to qualify Reserve, National Guard, and Active Component Soldiers in Combat Support Career Management Fields Under the Total Army School System(TASS). Provide Quality Instruction in MOS and NCOES Development Courses and Administer Instruction Qualification in TAITC and SGITC to Provide Top Notch Instructors.
2nd Battalion

The Mission of the 2nd Battalion is to qualify Reserve, National Guard, and Active Component Soldiers in Combat Support Career Management Fields Under the Total Army School System(TASS). Provide Quality Instruction in MOS and NCOES Development Courses. Upon Mobilization Augment the 108th Division (IT) Headquarters Staff; The Cadre and Faculty will be reassigned to Respective Branch School Based on Pre-designated Assignments.
3rd Battalion

The Mission of the 3rd Battalion (Health Services) is to qualify Reserve, National Guard, and Active Component Soldiers in Combat Support Career Management Fields Under the Total Army School System (TASS). Provide Quality Instruction in NCOES Development Courses for 91CMF BNCOC Phase II, 91 CMF ANCOC Phase II, and 91B BNCOC Phase IV. Provide Professional Development and Continuous Education Courses in the following: BCLS, NCLEX-PN, and NCLEX-RN.
4th Battalion

The PD batallion will provide Combined Arms and Service Staff School (CAS3) and CGSC instruction as mandate by the appropiate Proponent School Program of instruction (POI) to eligible students enrolled through ATTRS.
ROTC Brigade, 108th Division (TS)

The ROTC Brigade is a subordinate unit of the 108th Division (IT). The mission of the ROTC Brigade (Provisional) is to support Active Component ROTC Battalions in Region C of the Total Army School System (TASS) with personnel and training.
